R for Data Science

Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund wrote an incredible book called R for Data Science (R4DS). In the book they teach how to â€œturn raw data into understanding, insight, and knowledge.â€ The authors do this by being laser focused on the tools that help the data-practitioner import, tidy, transform, visualize, and model data (+communicate findings):

R4DS Workflow

I dug into the chapter on Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) this past week.

The chapter is ğŸ”¥ and I highly recommend it ğŸ˜

Exploring Data

I was super excited about the chapter and the knowledge it packed!

In my own path to improving my EDA skills I thought Iâ€™d capture what stuck out most in the form of a blog post.

EDA Overview

The authors of R4DS explain EDA as the process of â€œusing visualization and transformation to Explore your Data in a systematic way.â€ They recommend an iterative cycle as follows:

  1. Generate questions about your data.
  2. Search for answers by visualizing, transforming, and modeling your data.
  3. Use what you learn to refine your questions and/or generate new questions.

Favorite Quotes (from Intro)

The chapter was packed full of content - here are the quotes that stood out the most from the Introduction:

  • â€œEDA is not a formal process with a strict set of rules.â€

  • â€œEDA is a state of mind.â€ - I love this one ğŸ˜

  • â€œDuring the initial phases of EDA you should feel free to investigate every idea that occurs to you.â€

  • â€œAs your exploration continues, you will home in on a few particularly productive areas that youâ€™ll eventually write up and communicate to others.â€

Questions Drive EDA

One of my biggest take always from the chapter was the emphasis on EDA being a creative process that is driven by asking questions - and lots of them ğŸ¤”

Section on Questions

The section titled Questions was packed full of nuggets - here are a few of the quotes that stuck out:

  • â€œEDA is fundamentally a creative process.â€

  • â€œYour goal during EDA is to develop an understanding of your data. The easiest way to do this is to use questions as tools to guide your investigation.â€

  • â€œthe key to asking quality questions is to generate a large quantity of questions.â€ - So Good ğŸ˜

  • â€œeach new question that you ask will expose you to a new aspect of your data and increase your chance of making a discovery.â€

  • â€œThere is no rule about which questions you should ask to guide your research. However, two types of questions will always be useful for making discoveries within your data. You can loosely word these questions as:â€

  1. What type of variation occurs within my variables?
  2. What type of covariation occurs between my variables?

Section on Variation

We are always interested in discovering what explains the variation seen in data and so the section on Variation was very interesting. Here are a few of the quotes that stood out:

  • â€œVariation is the tendency of the values of a variable to change from measurement to measurement.â€

  • â€œEvery variable has its own pattern of variation, which can reveal interesting information.â€

  • â€œThe best way to understand that pattern is to visualize the distribution of the variableâ€™s values.â€

Visualizing Distributions

This post wouldnâ€™t be complete without a bit of code and a few visualizations ğŸ¤“

# load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(tidyquant)
library(patchwork)
theme_set(theme_tq())

Categorical Variables

  • â€œTo examine the distribution of a categorical variable, use a bar chart:â€
p1 <- ggplot(diamonds) +
    geom_bar(aes(x = cut)) +
    labs(title = "Bar Charts for Categorical Variables")
p1

Continuous Variables

  • â€œTo examine the distribution of a continuous variable, use a histogram:â€

  • â€œYou can set the width of the intervals in a histogram with the binwidth argument, which is measured in the units of the x variable.â€

p2 <- ggplot(diamonds %>% filter(carat < 3)) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = carat), binwidth = 1.0) +
    labs(title = "Binwidth: 1.0") 

p3 <- ggplot(diamonds %>% filter(carat < 3)) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = carat), binwidth = 0.5) +
    labs(title = "Binwidth = 0.5") 

p4 <- ggplot(diamonds %>% filter(carat < 3)) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = carat), binwidth = 0.1) +
    labs(title = "Binwidth = 0.1") 

p5 <- ggplot(diamonds %>% filter(carat < 3)) +
    geom_histogram(aes(x = carat), binwidth = 0.01) +
    labs(title = "Binwidth = 0.01")
  • â€œYou should always explore a variety of binwidths when working with histograms, as different binwidths can reveal different patterns.â€
# Show plots
patchwork <- p2 + p3 + p4 + p5

patchwork + plot_annotation(
  title   = "Histograms for Continuous Variables",
  caption = "Notice the different patterns that are revealed."
)

Typical Values

Remember how the authorâ€™s emphasize the use of questions to drive EDA?

This section on Typical Values continues that thread and suggests the following questions to ask when Visualizing Distributions:

  • â€œWhich values are the most common? Why?â€

  • â€œWhich values are rare? Why? Does that match your expectations?â€

  • â€œCan you see any unusual patterns? What might explain them?â€

Another learning from this section is to focus on the clusters revealed when Visualizing your Distributions. For example, take a look at the Histogram using a Binwidth of 0.01; obvious clusters are revealed that are not obvious in the other 3 plots.

p5

The authorâ€™s point out that â€œclusters of similar values suggest that subgroups exist in your data.â€

What do you think they suggest doing in this situation? Ask more questions ğŸ¤”

Understand the subgroups by asking:

  • â€œHow are the observations within each cluster similar to each other?â€

  • â€œHow are the observations in separate clusters different from each other?â€

  • â€œHow can you explain or describe the clusters?â€

  • â€œWhy might the appearance of clusters be misleading?â€

Wrap Up

The chapter goes on to discuss unusual values, missing values, covariation, and briefly goes into using models to further your EDA. I highly recommend giving it a read and trying out the exercises in the chapter.

Get the code here: Github Repo.

Questions. Questions. Questions.

The biggest learning I took from this chapter, and what Iâ€™ve started using in my own EDA process, is getting better at asking questions. Not only that, but really to let my curiosity drive the EDA early on in the process.

And my favorite quote is probably this one:

â€œthe key to asking quality questions is to generate a large quantity of questions.â€
